what: Installing randomforge and running a simple randomization
title: Contributing to randomforge
text: stage, package yet CRAN. can install development version directly GitHub: minimal example demonstrates simple permuted block randomization workflow.
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("RCONIS/randomforge") library(randomforge) #> randomforge developer version 0.1.0.9046 loaded  # Create an in-memory randomization database randomDataBase <- getRandomDataBase()  # Define a project and configuration randomProject <- getRandomProject("Example Trial") randomDataBase$persist(randomProject)  # Create a randomization configuration config <- getRandomConfiguration(     randomProject        = randomProject,     treatmentArmIds      = c("A", "B"),     seed                 = createSeed(),     ravBufferMinimumSize = 1000L,     ravBufferMaximumSize = 10000L )  randomDataBase$persist(config)  # Define fixed block size blockSizes <- getBlockSizes(config$treatmentArmIds, 8)  # Create a permuted block randomization method randomMethodPBR <- getRandomMethodPBR(     blockSizes = blockSizes )  # Create a random allocation value service ravService <- getRandomAllocationValueService() ravService$createNewRandomAllocationValues(config) #> Create 9000 new random allocation values (seed = 8850860)  # Create a few randomization results resultList <- lapply(1:8, function(i) {     suppressMessages(getNextRandomResult(         randomDataBase               = randomDataBase,         randomProject                = randomProject,         randomMethod                 = randomMethodPBR,         randomAllocationValueService = ravService     )) })  # Convert results to a data frame randomDataBase |>      as.data.frame() |>     knitr::kable()

title: Framework for Clinical Trial Randomization Methods
text: Randomization cornerstone clinical research integrity. Yet many tools currently use : proprietary closed, difficult extend integrate, opaque assignments generated, designed collaborative innovation. randomforge aims change providing open, shared infrastructure randomization methods ‚Äì ideas can grow trusted, well-documented practically usable methods, developed together community.

title: Framework for Clinical Trial Randomization Methods
text: current version randomforge focuses robust core permuted block randomization (PBR), built extensibility mind. Already implemented: Support fixed random block sizes Support multi-arm designs getRandomProject() define trial project getRandomConfiguration() configure treatment arms, seeds buffer sizes getRandomDataBase() manage projects, configurations, results subjects S3 method .data.frame.RandomDataBase() inspect randomized subjects Stratum identifiers automatically constructed named factor levels getRandomAllocationValueService() manage underlying random number stream writeExcelFile() export randomization subject lists Excel file getTreatmentArmValueList() construct arm-specific values, e.g.¬†allocation ratios block compositions internal architecture uses reference classes represent key entities like RandomProject, RandomConfiguration, RandomBlock, RandomSubject, RandomSystemState. makes easier extend engine additional randomization methods future (e.g., covariate-adaptive response-adaptive procedures).

title: Framework for Clinical Trial Randomization Methods
text: current release focuses permuted block randomization, randomforge initiative designed cover much wider range techniques time, including (limited ): baseline-adaptive covariate-adaptive methods (e.g.¬†minimization), response-adaptive randomization, advanced stratification & centre structures, enhanced auditing reporting facilities, integration Shiny UIs web APIs, validation documentation patterns suitable regulated environments.

title: Framework for Clinical Trial Randomization Methods
text: example illustrates minimal workflow using currently implemented PBR engine. shows : create project configuration, choose block randomization method, repeatedly request next randomization result, inspect resulting subject-level randomization data frame.
code: library(randomforge)  # Create an in-memory randomization database randomDataBase <- getRandomDataBase()  # Define a project and configuration randomProject <- getRandomProject("Example Trial") randomDataBase$persist(randomProject)  # Create a randomization configuration config <- getRandomConfiguration(     randomProject        = randomProject,     treatmentArmIds      = c("A", "B"),     seed                 = createSeed(),     ravBufferMinimumSize = 1000L,     ravBufferMaximumSize = 10000L ) config  randomDataBase$persist(config)  # Define variable block sizes blockSizes <- getBlockSizes(config$treatmentArmIds, c(4, 6))  # Define a block randomization method blockSizeRandomizer <- getRandomBlockSizeRandomizer(blockSizes) blockSizeRandomizer  randomMethodPBR <- getRandomMethodPBR(     blockSizes              = blockSizes,     fixedBlockDesignEnabled = FALSE,     blockSizeRandomizer     = blockSizeRandomizer )  # Create a random allocation value service ravService <- getRandomAllocationValueService() ravService$createNewRandomAllocationValues(config)  # Visualize the distribution of the random allocation values plot(ravService, usedValuesOnly = FALSE)  # Create a few randomization results lapply(1:5, function(i) {     getNextRandomResult(         randomDataBase               = randomDataBase,         randomProject                = randomProject,         randomMethod                 = randomMethodPBR,         randomAllocationValueService = ravService     ) })  # Convert results to a data frame as.data.frame(randomDataBase)
